sec_txt.h3: The Big Debate: Pharmacologic vs Alternative Approaches in Smoking Cessation
Program Agenda
The Importance of a Complete Quit
Worldwide Leading Causes of Attributable Global Mortality[1]
Smoking Leads to an 11-Year Loss of Life Span[2]
Mortality and Morbidity Rates Associated With Smoking[2,3]

ul.li:
The figure on the left shows that there is a monotonous dose effect relationship between cigarettes per day and all-cause mortality
This means that even low smoking rates are associated with an increased risk of mortality
In the specific case of cardiovascular disease, most of the mortality risk is borne by low smoking rates, as seen in the curve on the right

sec_txt.h3: Mortality and Morbidity Rates Associated With Smoking (cont)[2,4]
All-Cause Mortality Risk Reduction After Quitting Smoking[5]

ul.li: It is believed that complete quit is the safest and most effective way to reduce the all-cause mortality associated with smoking
It is also believed that the reduction of all-cause mortality stabilizes roughly 10 to 15 years after complete smoking cessation

sec_txt.h3: Little Evidence of All-Cause Mortality Risk Reduction After Smoking Reduction[6-9]

ul.li: It is important to keep in mind that in all the studies shown on this slide, smoking reduction was not supported by any nicotine replacement use
Moreover, it is known that reduction of cigarettes per day does not reflect reduction of toxin exposure

sec_txt.h3: Harm Reduction Concept: People Who Do Not Want to Give Up Tobacco or Nicotine Use Completely[10]
Cigarette Smoking Causes the Most Harm[11]
Conclusions
Pharmacologic Therapies for Smoking Cessation: The Evidence
Nicotine Replacement Therapy vs Control for Smoking Cessation[12]

ul.li: Nicotine replacement therapy is the oldest, most established, and most used therapy for smoking cessation

Based on the results of this analysis, the Cochrane Group collaborators stated that they will never do another meta-analysis of this type, because the evidence is so strong for nicotine replacement against placebo
Subgroup and other types of analyses may be conducted, for example, comparing nicotine replacement with e-cigarettes or other comparators, but the placebo comparison is firmly established at this time

sec_txt.h3: First-Line Drugs in Smoking Cessation: Meta-Analysis of Cochrane Register Efficacy Data[12-15]
Efficacy of Varenicline: Phase 3 and 4 Studies (Weeks 9-12)[16-25]
Efficacy of Varenicline: Phase 3 and 4 Studies (Weeks 9-52)[16,17,21-23,25]
Quit Rates Flexible Quit Date Study[24]
Varenicline Maintenance Study[26]
Maintenance Treatment With Varenicline in Patients With Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorder[27]
EAGLES: Continuous Abstinence Rates in Psychiatric and Nonpsychiatric Cohorts[28]

ul.li: This is the EAGLES study and included over 8000 subjects, both people with psychiatric disease and people without known psychiatric disease
The study was sponsored by both producers of varenicline and of bupropion and in collaboration with health authorities

sec_txt.h3: Primary Endpoint for the EAGLES Study: Nonpsychiatric Adverse Events[28]
Tolerability and Safety Issues[29]
Physician Perspectives[30]
Lack of Readiness to Use Pharmacologic Options (Smoker)
E-Cigarettes and "Heat-Not-Burn" Devices: Is There a Role?
Current Controversy

ul.li: In my opinion, what we see in our field is this split in the attitude to e-cigarettes, which I believe is based on priority

If the priority is smoke-related death and disease, then there is a sort of pragmatic perspective in which alternative lower-risk nicotine devices may appear as promising to lower the total of death and disease from smoking

By contrast, the other view is the concern that providing nicotine in the less dangerous form still maintains and may even increase nicotine use in the population
Hence, safe nicotine devices are both a problem and a risk
